review.title: A Novel Pre-processing Scheme to Improve the Prediction of Sand Fraction from Seismic Attributes using Neural Networks
review.abstract: This paper presents a novel pre-processing scheme to improve the prediction of sand fraction from multiple seismic attributes such as seismic impedance, amplitude and frequency using machine learning and information filtering. The available well logs along with the 3-D seismic data have been used to benchmark the proposed pre-processing stage using a methodology which primarily consists of three steps: pre-processing, training and post-processing. An Artificial Neural Network (ANN) with conjugate-gradient learning algorithm has been used to model the sand fraction. The available sand fraction data from the high resolution well logs has far more information content than the low resolution seismic attributes. Therefore, regularization schemes based on Fourier Transform (FT), Wavelet Decomposition (WD) and Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD) have been proposed to shape the high resolution sand fraction data for effective machine learning. The input data sets have been segregated into training, testing and validation sets. The test results are primarily used to check different network structures and activation function performances. Once the network passes the testing phase with an acceptable performance in terms of the selected evaluators, the validation phase follows. In the validation stage, the prediction model is tested against unseen data. The network yielding satisfactory performance in the validation stage is used to predict lithological properties from seismic attributes throughout a given volume. Finally, a post-processing scheme using 3-D spatial filtering is implemented for smoothing the sand fraction in the volume. Prediction of lithological properties using this framework is helpful for Reservoir Characterization.
histories: 13 pages, volume 8, no 4, pp. 1808-1820, April 2015 in IEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing, 2015

sections.heading: II. STUDY AREA AND WORKFLOW
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Study Area
sections.text: This study will acquire work data from the western onshore carbon field in India. The carbon dioxide field is located in an intracratonic basin that spreads along the western periphery of central India. It is surrounded by hydrocarbonates, which are located in a series of vertically stacked sandstone reservoirs. Structurally, the field is designated as a broad slope area.

sections.heading: B. Workflow
sections.text: The systematic workflow, which consists of three phases, such as pre-processing, model-making validation and post-processing, is demonstrated in Fig. 2. The workflow is implemented on a 64-bit MATLAB platform installed in Dell Precision M6800, with Intel ® core ™ i7-4700MQ CPU @ 2.40 GHz with 32 GB of RAM. sections.heading: III. PRE-PROCESSING
sections.text: Pre-processing plays a crucial role in the performance of a machine learning algorithm. This paper proposes an efficient pre-processing approach as part of the applied methodology to establish a functional relationship between seismic attributes and lithological properties.

sections.heading: A. Signal Reconstruction
sections.text: Conversely, seismic data is collected spatially in the time domain with a sampling interval of two milliseconds. Signal reconstruction is an important step before processing and has been discussed in existing literature. In [20], the upscaling of an acoustic impedance protocol was performed using a waveform-based method and a geostatistical technique, the acoustic impedance protocol is calculated from the recorded wave velocity and density logs at the appropriate well location. Reconstructed acoustic impedance logs obtained from the raw impedance protocol using wave transformation and geostatistical methods have been found to be similar. [21] the seismic attributes and well intervals are integrated to predict facies using a data-driven methodology.

sections.heading: V. POST-PROCESSING
sections.text: It can be observed from Fig. 8 that the variation in seismic attributes over the study area is smooth. However, the sand fraction in the study area, as shown in Fig. 9, is abrupt; the transition of the CRC values should be smoother and more or less aligned with the patterns of seismic data, thus increasing the need for post-processing to obtain a smoother sand fractionation variant in the volume. To incorporate this rationality, the predicted values are filtered through a 3-D filter. Median filter is a statistical filter that is not linear.

metadata.abstractText: This paper presents a novel pre-processing scheme to improve the prediction of sand fraction from multiple seismic attributes such as seismic impedance, amplitude and frequency using machine learning and information filtering. The available well logs along with the 3-D seismic data have been used to benchmark the proposed pre-processing stage using a methodology which primarily consists of three steps: preprocessing, training and post-processing. An Artificial Neural Network (ANN) with conjugate-gradient learning algorithm has been used to model the sand fraction. The available sand fraction data from the high resolution well logs has far more information content than the low resolution seismic attributes. Therefore, regularization schemes based on Fourier Transform (FT), Wavelet Decomposition (WD) and Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD) have been proposed to shape the high resolution sand fraction data for effective machine learning. The input data sets have been segregated into training, testing and validation sets. The test results are primarily used to check different network structures and activation function performances. Once the network passes the testing phase with an acceptable performance in terms of the selected evaluators, the validation phase follows. In the validation stage, the prediction model is tested against unseen data. The network yielding satisfactory performance in the validation stage is used to predict lithological properties from seismic attributes throughout a given volume. Finally, a post-processing scheme using 3-D spatial filtering is implemented for smoothing the sand fraction in the volume. Prediction of lithological properties using this framework is helpful for Reservoir Characterization.
